statement.text: Sartorius muscle flap is a tissue transposition technique used to cover and protect vascular grafts in the groin when wound complications occur or are anticipated. The sartorius muscle is mobilized from its origin at the anterior superior iliac spine (ASIS), rotated medially, and sutured over the femoral vessels and anastomoses. This provides vascularized tissue coverage that promotes healing, protects against graft exposure, and may help contain localized infection.
statement.formal: Sartorius Flap: Detach muscle from ASIS origin → Preserve distal blood supply (femoral artery branches) → Rotate medially over femoral vessels → Suture to inguinal ligament/adductor fascia | Indications: Groin wound dehiscence, graft exposure, prophylactic coverage | Function: Provides vascularized tissue over graft

explanation.intuition: The sartorius muscle is like a built-in bandage that's already in the neighborhood. It's a long, strap-like muscle on the front of your thigh that you can disconnect at the top and swing over to cover the blood vessels in the groin, like flipping a blanket over something you want to protect. Because it has its own blood supply from below, it stays alive and brings healing power to the area.
explanation.key_insight: The sartorius flap is your go-to salvage maneuver when a groin wound is failing. It's reliable, easy to perform, and doesn't require microsurgical expertise. The key is detaching only the origin (at the ASIS) while preserving the segmental blood supply from branches of the femoral artery entering the muscle from below.
explanation.technical_details: Technique: (1) Extend groin incision laterally if needed; (2) Identify sartorius muscle at the lateral border of the femoral triangle; (3) Identify the anterior superior iliac spine (ASIS); (4) Incise the fascia along the lateral border of sartorius; (5) Develop a plane under the muscle, preserving segmental blood supply from femoral artery perforators; (6) Divide the origin of sartorius at the ASIS (be careful of lateral femoral cutaneous nerve); (7) Rotate the muscle medially over the femoral vessels; (8) Suture the muscle to the inguinal ligament superiorly and adductor fascia medially using absorbable sutures; (9) The muscle should comfortably cover the femoral artery and graft; (10) Close skin if possible, or use negative pressure wound therapy if needed.
common_misconceptions: You need to detach both ends of the muscle - only detach the origin, preserve distal attachments
The muscle will die after transposition - it has segmental blood supply that is preserved
This is only for infected wounds - prophylactic use in high-risk patients is common
Any groin wound needs a sartorius flap - most wounds heal primarily, flap is for problems

definitions_glossary.sartorius_muscle: Long strap muscle from ASIS to medial tibia, flexes and rotates thigh
definitions_glossary.anterior_superior_iliac_spine: Bony prominence at front of iliac crest, origin of sartorius
definitions_glossary.segmental_blood_supply: Multiple blood vessel branches along length of muscle
definitions_glossary.muscle_flap: Muscle with its blood supply mobilized for tissue coverage
definitions_glossary.lateral_femoral_cutaneous_nerve: Sensory nerve near ASIS, provides sensation to lateral thigh

indications: Groin wound dehiscence with exposed vascular graft
Prophylactic coverage in high-risk patients (obese, diabetic, redo surgery)
Lymphatic leak with groin wound breakdown
Skin loss over groin precluding primary closure
contraindications: Gross graft infection with systemic sepsis (graft may need to be removed)

technique.positioning: Supine with leg slightly abducted and externally rotated
technique.incision: Extend existing groin incision laterally toward ASIS

key_structures.sartorius_muscle: Lateral border of femoral triangle, strap-shaped
key_structures.lateral_femoral_cutaneous_nerve: Crosses near ASIS, protect if possible
key_structures.segmental_perforators: From femoral artery, preserve throughout muscle length

steps: Identify sartorius at lateral femoral triangle border
Develop plane under muscle, preserving perforators
Identify and protect lateral femoral cutaneous nerve
Suture to inguinal ligament and adductor fascia
Close skin or apply wound VAC

closure.skin_loss: Negative pressure wound therapy until granulation, then skin graft

complications.prevention: Preserve segmental blood supply, don't stretch excessively
complications.management: Debridement, alternative coverage (rectus femoris, omental flap)

complications.prevention: Identify and protect nerve near ASIS

complications.management: Further debridement, may need graft excision

complications.incidence: Minimal (sartorius is not a major hip flexor)

outcomes.graft_preservation: 75-85% when flap used for graft complications
outcomes.functional_deficit: Minimal to none (sartorius is not essential for function)

definition.@value: Surgical technique of mobilizing and rotating the sartorius muscle to cover and protect femoral vessels and vascular grafts in the groin

sources.citation: Rutherford's Vascular Surgery, 9th Edition. Management of Vascular Wound Complications.
Seeger JM, et al. Muscle flap coverage for vascular graft infections. J Vasc Surg.

learning_objectives: Describe the anatomy of the sartorius muscle and its blood supply
Perform sartorius muscle flap transposition for groin coverage
Identify indications for prophylactic vs therapeutic sartorius flap
Manage complications of groin wound with muscle flap coverage
clinical_pearls: Only detach the origin at the ASIS - the blood supply comes from below
The lateral femoral cutaneous nerve is right at the ASIS - watch for it
Consider prophylactic sartorius flap in obese, diabetic, or redo groin cases
If skin won't close, use wound VAC until granulation, then skin graft
This is a straightforward muscle flap - don't hesitate to use it when needed

medicalCode.description: Muscle, myocutaneous, or fasciocutaneous flap; trunk
Transfer upper leg muscle, open approach
